Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition  is a frenzied, artistic action game that, though it is marred by slight technical difficulties, still provides an enjoyable alternative to the standard action-sandbox.   Sleeping Dogs ' greatest strength comes from its presentation. The developers implemented the game's open-world replica of Hong Kong painstakingly with striking visuals and smartly interconnected layouts, which help the player see this beautifully-realized city from all angles. The characters' presentations are also done in an effective manner. The effort put into the story of the main character especially pays off, as gamers can easily identify with the upbringing and struggles that drive development of protagonist Wei Shen as he searches to define himself between connections with the Hong Kong Police and the gang Sun On Yee. Wei is joined by a cast of secondary characters that would generally fall into the category of 'stereotypical', but fortunately most have some extraordinary developments or twists that keep them from becoming stale or predictable.  Comparisons between  Sleeping Dogs  and the  Grand Theft Auto  series are commonplace. However, such claims made in an attempt to denigrate  Sleeping Dogs  is, at best, ignorant. Martial arts motifs play a significant role in the design of the gameplay here, composing the greatest difference between this and GTA. The player lacks the GTA-standard arsenal of weapons to carry around as combat is largely focused on hand-to-hand combat. Though some later levels heavily feature guns, players will largely find themseleves using combos and counters to dispatch foes. Other mechanics, ranging from a unique on-the-road hijack system to genre-standard slow-motion sequences further reinforce the kung-fu movie feel that the game is going for.   Sleeping Dogs  suffers from an array of technical malfunctions and limitations. The game in general works appropriately (no issues with rendering or framerate), though on rare occasion it crashed with no warning. Because the game generates cutscenes and scripted actions in the real game environment (i.e. instead of cutscenes being full video, the background of the scene is a continuation of what is going on with NPCs in the open world), unintended consequences often result. These consequences range from the hilarious (two characters showing indifference after being run over during a cutscene) to the catastrophic (being stuck behind an invisible wall after a scripted event, requiring reset). Getting stuck is moreso an issue with platforming in this game, as it attempts to emulate  Assassin's Creed 's parkour system, only to provide an unrefined version, leaving many instances of floating above objets or glitching around walls where one shouldn't be. Finally, the overreliance on the counter mechanism during combat makes it difficult to fight off groups of enemies as the game cannot handle many targets to counter at once. This proves especially troublesome during the beginning of the game, when Wei is too weak to take most attacks and must abuse the counter, leading to some unfair situations. This becomes less of an issue as he grows stronger in the game.  In spite of this variety of issues the game faces, it was never enough to outweigh the positive experience that playing this game provided. It offers a lengthy primary campaign, bolstered by sidequests, completion goals and simple-yet-fun minigames. The  Definitive Edition  provides a significant amount of bonus missions and accessories to effectively bolster the length of the game after beating the main game. Additionally, it provides two scenarios seperate from the main game to play, which are both worthwhile in their own right. Though the final result of the game faced faulty implementation due to what the game was trying to accomplish, it still succeeds in providing a more visually-enthralling, narrative driven experience than is normal for action sandbox titles, and is a worthy game in any collection.  Sleeping Dogs: Definitive Edition  gets a B.

I'll start this by saying that I've really enjoyed this game. A good mix between GTA and Saints Row. Story is cliche but engaging at the same time, although I was really hoping that there would be multiple endings at the end (it seemed like the story was leading to that). The game's story had the potential to top GTA's if they had put in multiple endings.  GTA should do collectables like how Sleeping Dogs did it. The problem with GTA's collectables is that they had no value to it. Sleeping Dogs gave you upgrades for completing collectables. Thus, giving you the reason to go hunting them down.  Combat system is one of the best for this genre, forcing you to use martial arts instead of going in guns blazing (not true for all missions, as the last few missions were gunfights). And note that I said 'for this genre'. Combat is definately not as good as the Batman series or Shadow of Mordor. And the chase scenes are amazing, as the freerunning system is simple but engaging at the same time.  Problems only come in when you're trying to get all achevements and 100% the whole game. Bugs start to show, and I had to restart missions multiple times (sometimes even the whole game). Missions became tedious to do. At this point, the game got frustrating and I was playing it for the sake of completion. But this all started after the 25-30 hour mark.  DLCs were mostly meh... 'Nightmare in North Point' was OK. You would probably enjoy 'Year of the Snake' if you really enjoyed the police missions in the main game.  TL;DR Main story cliche but good. Brings new mechanics to the table for this genre. DLCs are meh. Game can become tedious and frustrating when trying to 100% it. Highly recommended.  BTW, always remember, 'A man who never eats pork buns is never a whole man.'

Cool game, lovely voice work and great graphics. The environments are nice and the combat is fun. However there is one thing that I cannot shake when I play this and it is very irritating. It feels like a poor man's GTA. Driving vehicles is no fun either, mostly because when using a mouse and keyboard, the camera is awkward. Reversing on a bike will spin the camera, but if you manually move the mouse to get a better look as you set off forward, it will still rotate the camera and as such go beyond the forward view - as if it has to complete the entire motion. Why they couldn't of made it so moving the camera view yourself resets the camera spin, I just don't know.  There are are a few other minor annoyances. Sometimes AI will walk into things, which isn't that bad really and many games are guilty of that (ahem Payday 2), but one of my biggest gripes when playing on foot is that there is no toggle for walk and run. Instead, if you want to walk you must rely on holding the free aim button (which is right click by default). However using free aim to walk is evidently not the proper way of doing it because whenever you get near an interactable object that you wish to talk past, your guy will just... sort of strafe past it while trying to get it in focus. Bit daft really that they couldn't simply add a walk toggle button.  Another annoyance? The weird buttons. The game plays brilliantly with mouse and keyboard, but I have no idea why some menus rely solely on pressing Left-CTRL and Right-CTRL and Backspace and Enter. Why couldn't a cursor be implemented? Seems a bit lazy if you ask me.  Overall, of what I've played (among some other very minor bugs which I've decided not to mention here), the game is excellent and well worth the money if you haven't already got the base game. For those who have the original Sleeping Dogs, I wouldn't necessarily say the increase in graphical fidelity and draw distance was worth it... although that is ultimately your decision.

The game is very good overall, espicially the amount of NPCs, the smoke ffect and the story line. Introducing the technology of HBAO+ and TXAA to the game will also be a good idea and I extremely recommend people to buy it.

Sleeping Dogs: DE edition is why steam needs more review options than either yes/no - Sleeping Dogs is a game that I would give a neutral review on, the gameplay has varied amount of issues and bugs but also occasionally is great fun to play. Sleeping Dogs is the epitome of take two steps forward and three steps backwards, hopefully SE will decide on making a sequel and address many of the issues that keep Sleeping Dogs from being a masterpiece.   +Great Graphics +Great setting and story +Good fighting mechanics +Plenty of action sequences +Lots of side missions +Good voice actors  -Poor racing missions, especially bike races -Questionable vehicle handling -Many bugs and occasional crashes -Poor gunplay -Frustrating missions -Useless weapons especially guns  There are many questionable design flaws in Sleeping Dogs which really don't help the game, such as several highly useless abilities like access police weapons from the trunks of police cars, alls this does is immediately start a police chase, not that the guns will help you since they'll disappear if you interact with the world - yes, you heard that currently since SE constantly defend the fact that this is a melee based game, they state that guns are a 'power-up' but that doesn't explain why if I use a health shrine or open a box, or do anything other than shoot the gun will mysteriously disappear - this renders all the DLC that have bonus weapons completely useless.   Hong Kong looks great - plenty of eye candy all around but even so, SE fails to go beyond that - the character customization is limited, clothing is limited with few giving XP or special boosts. Car customization is non-existant which is a shame and doesn't really make that much sense since a large portion of content revolves around illegal street racing, which brings up another major issue - the racing is exceptionally poor, the car races are 100% based on picking the correct car for the race, its as simple as that - whilst the bike racing is mind blowing bad, your rival racers seem to ride ungodly powerful bikes that go significantly faster, have insanely perfect handling around tight spaces and have godly acceleration, the only chances the player has to win the bike races is to have the best bikes and to drive the race with perfection, no crashes, no drift errors - as your rivals will slow down at certain parts allowing you to get in front, and then catch just as quickly.   In closing, whilst I'm giving this a recommedation, this game does have its issues so I would rather give it a mixed review rather than a purely postive one. I would say this game is worth a purchase if on sale or cheap but be aware of potential issues.

So in this game you play as an immoral wank*r (Triad Member) who is actually a professional wank*r (Police Officer) in a city once ruled by imperial wank*rs (Hong Kong). Yup... and you can be sure that my psycho-side was in full force when I played this. I just couldn't help myself. XD  It's basically a sandbox crime game, but with the added twist of you sometimes doing sandbox stuff where you punch crime instead. Or taze it. Or shoot it. Or arrest it. Or... yeah not continuing this. Anyway, there's lots of side missions, collectibles, places to explore, minigames, and citizens to beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of when they make rude remarks about your clothes, hit you with their car, or just simply exist. Honestly, I didn't need reasons to act like a total sociopath (even moreso than I do in the Saints Row games, which is really saying something), so I had a tendency to act like one...  ...except during alot of missions when it actually has negative effects. Basically you have three leveling systems: Police (which you get xp for by obeying the law and punching criminals on police missions), Triad (for punching people or slamming their head into... woah that was uncalled for), and Face (for helping people, which I find funny since pride pretty much never involves being a benefactor). It's pretty obvious which of these three leveling systems I didn't get much XP for. The minigames were kinda silly, particularly that karaoke stuff and the whole collecting girl phone numbers thing (which I never called because I never got  that  bored). At least the combat is pretty good.  There is a story, and it's actually pretty good. At times predictable, and I often felt as if my main character was being way too antagonistic towards his police handler. But it's good. Also its crazy-violent, because gangsters who talk about codes and honor are the last people to actually respect such things. And while I was not torn at all about whose side I was on (because Triad people are scum), I did cheer a few times when they did stuff I wanted them to do, such as when the character I hated the most (because he pulled a Walder Frey, which made me think about the 'RW' and all that comes with that) ended up being killed by a crazed lady feeding him one of his henchmen and chopping him with a meat cleaver. And while that was certainly satisfying, it wasn't one of the  many  ideas I had between the 'Hong Kong RW' and that scene about what way I would have ended that guy (or Walder Frey). I had an alarming tendency to ponder what outrageous act of violence I wanted to see end the lives of certain characters, most of which were more brutal than what actually happened. I really must be a psycho. >_<  Anyway... sandbox crime, violence, betrayal... all that horse-♥♥♥♥. There isn't really anything new here, and while I certainly prefer other games (like the Saints Row series) for this type of fun, this is alright. So I guess that's a 'yes' from me.  Yey.

There are literally HUNDREDS of collectibles to find and grab; some giving you new combat skills, outfits and access to cameras around Hong Kong.  All the animations are realistic and just fun to look at.  There are a myriad of vehicles to use, ranging from the outrageous Super-fast bikes to the downright stupidly slow skrub cars you find on the street.  In short, this game is damn fun and interesting, with a ton of sidequests to do and things to be found. Also there's infinite stamina so yay... and stuff... and stuff...  -Scooter 2012

Would I recommend this? That's actually not a 'yes' or a 'no'. If you do not own the original, then yes, I would recommend you buy this, as Sleeping Dogs is, in my opinion, a very brilliant and under-rated game. If you do own the original, then, no, I wouldn't recommend it unless you like the look of enough of the DLC available that you don't already have that this will actually end up being cheaper than buying that DLC. Why do I say this? Well, the graphics, once you actually get them working right, do show improvement over the original, and the world feels a bit more populated, but the difference is more of a case of a minor nip and tuck, rather than a jaw-dropping overhaul, so it's not really worth even the discounted price for that alone.

This game is gruesome in an all-too-good way. If you want an actually biting and well-engineered game with the message that crime doesn't pay, play this game. It demonstrates exactly why the criminal lifestyle is bad without forcing it down your throat or completely jerking your chain like GTA4 does. You lose friends - emotionally and literally - you make enemies, you suffer, you bleed, you break, you hurt, and some things you just have to let go in order to live. Hong Kong is a beautiful and mean place, and you get to find out first-hand just how terrible it can be to be a gangster.  Visually and audibly this game is absolutely beautiful even despite the dicky optimization on PC, and its gameplay is so satisfying and free-feeling even when you're just blitzing main quests like I did my first time around. The first time you roll around the neon-lit Hong Kong at night while listening to chilled out electronic tracks on Ninja Tune will take your breath away, I guarantee it.   Story-wise, the story can be a BIT spotty, but it's hardly gaping with holes and it's easy to suspend your disbelief to understand them. The developers seemed to actually care about the fact that you might want to cut loose and plough through a shopping district sometimes after a hard mission, so you only get punished for murder through police attention and, if you're on a mission, reduced Cop XP rather than revoking money or XP retroactively.  The characters are also REALLY likeable and surprisingly memorable even with such a wide cast. You will learn to love Jackie Ma, you will learn to loathe Dogeyes, and you will learn to breathe like Wei Shen.  Hong Kong is a cruel place, but it's also a beautiful place. This game makes me want to visit it for real. Do not pass up your chance to play this, if you ever get it.

Sleeping Dogs was, is and always will be one of my favorite games. Before I review, note that the description is lying. It doesn't include all availaible DLC's. But it does include two major ones.   So you're probably wondering whether Sleeping Dogs has anything to do with sleeping dogs. Nope. Just like Watch_Dogs has nothing to do with watching dogs. It might be a tad boring that way. Just a tad. You play as an undercover cop named Wei Shen who's job and goal is to take down the notorious Triad Sun On Yee gang in Hong Kong. The story plays out really well and characters have good voice acting and are memorable.  If you haven't played the original (which is unfortunately not available anymore on PC) you wouldn't notice the difference in graphics. The only two noticeable changes I saw is the lighting and amount of people on the streets; which already makes for a much more fun experience as it makes Hong Kong feel much more alive. There are some minor annoyances but nothing game breaking. Cars and motorcycles pinball off of walls and other cars and sometimes combos and counters don't register. But it doesn't happen often. I very highly recommend this game as it delivers unique combat on foot and in cars. Which reminds me....to those of you patiently waiting for Arkham Knight, this will fill the whole for a bit as you can unlock (basically) the Chinese Batmobile. It will gain upgrades as you do more missions with it.  That's the end of my review. This paragraph is for those curious to gain knowledge past playing the game. Sleeping Dogs is based on true events. How true? That I don't know but I do know this. The fictious Sun On Yee gang is based on a real Triad gang called the Sun Yee On. And the 18K is based on the Sun Yee On's real arch rivals the 14K. Sun Yee On was founded in 1919 by a man named Heung Chin and currently has around 55,000 members around the world; which is supposedly the highest count among the Triads. The Triads control extortion, drug trafficking, gambling and prostitution. Which is basically everything you encounter in the game. Their favored weapon of choice is the cleaver; which you see plenty of in the game as well. The Triads do not give any mercy to traitors and rats. They do indeed torture their victims before killing them. The term 'red pole' is also a real term used and is actually not a huge deal within their structure. 'Red poles' are enforcers; just one step up from being regular members. Before you were even in the Sun On Yee you were considered a 'Blue Lantern' which is the uninitiated. The initiated and regular members are considered '49ers'.   The characters you see in the game are based off of actual people; but the names were changed to protect them. There is also a reason why Wei Shen came from San Francisco. The Triads were really noticed by the US in 1977 due to the 'Golden Dragon Massacre'. The attack resulted in 5 deaths and 11 wounded. 2 of which were tourists and the other 9 weren't gang members either. This event led to the creation of the 'San Francisco Asian Gang Task Force'.  People usually tend to think that videogames aren't educational and they teach you absolutely nothing. This is....the definitive way to prove those people wrong AHAHA....I'm sorry I couldn't resist. Little to no change from the original release. Playing the game at 3840x2160 with maximum available settings, still provides mediocre visual fidelity in contrast to other titles. The main city area itself has a large amount of content to explore, side missions to take part in, and police objectives to clear. The driving can feel out of place at times if you are in the wrong vehicle, although the action cameras and jumping from car to car provide options for changing that.   The Definitive Edition is another way of saying 'DLC.' That is what you get, the original copy of the game with all included DLC. If you are expecting a full 'remaster,' you will not find it here. Only subtle changes to the graphics have been applied, and more times than not, they are just additional effects to fill the empty spaces of the city.   I picked up the game at a massive discount, and I suggest you do as well. As years later, it is not worth anywhere near the full price they are requesting, and feels more like a 'cash grab' than anything else. Especially with the lackluster improvements to the core elements that make up Sleeping Dogs.   If you don't own the game, it is a good time sink between other games. You can't go wrong with a discount purchase.

This game is Asian GTA. If you like GTA or Saints Row you should definitely buy this game. Among the game's many positives are: Hong Kong culture, Triad culture, a great variety of soundtrack, a focus on martial arts instead of just shooting up everything, and an amazing story. The tension in the story comes from Wei Shen's equivocal position between being an undercover cop, and being a rogue who has a personal vendetta to dominate Hong Kong's underworld.   There are a few frustrating things about the game. If you're playing the PC version, the menus feel a bit laggy, and there are a couple of missions where counterattacks just do not register consistently (Death by a Thousand Cuts). Read the YouTube comments on this mission for hilarity. Another bug is when you throw a knife at someone, and it bounces off of them at high speed and instantly kills you (even from full health).   If there is one piece of advice I can give you, it is to look up what the fastest vehicles are for each type of race and to buy them, because some races are absolutely impossible to win without the right vehicle (try winning a B-class race with the HKPD SUV -- use the Terre GT instead) . In the races, the computer-controlled drivers will often ram you at the start (asian drivers), and if you find yourself being overtaken on a straightaway it's because you have an underpowered vehicle.   Another tip is to use the uniform that gives double cop XP for all of the missions that are colored blue. Even without the uniform, it is easiest to max out cop xp for the bonuses, almost as easy to max out face xp, and very difficult to max out Triad XP.   Other than trying to win races without buying the fastest vehicles, and the sometimes inconsistent fighting mechanics (laggy registers on counterattack timings), this game truly has an amazing story that should not be missed by anyone who is a fan of the open world GTA style games. Buy Asian GTA.

That alone tells you how awesome this game is, Everything from it's incredible and exciting storyline to the street vendors' dialogue is as close to perfect as I've seen.  Pros: - The main storyline (All Sun On Yee-related missions) is like being in a really good action movie. That's the best way I can describe it. The writing, cinematography, and character development is spot-on. - The characters is this game feel like real people. The writing and voice acting is superb. This, both fortunately and unfortunately makes it easy to get connecting to a character. You'll understand why that's a 'bad' things when you play. - The environment of Hong Kong iss so many different great things. It's gritty, dirty, vibrant, bright, dark, beautiful, etc. It's what it needs to be when that is appropriate. You never feel out of place in this game unless the game wants you to feel out of place. Also, civilian dialogue in this game is great. It acts as a comic-relief and is probably my favorite thing about this game, other than the pork buns. - The combat in this game, both melee and armed, is great. Abviously it has a much more in-depth melee system, but the gunplay is fun and satisfying as well. I've always thought of the melee in this game as what The Batman: Arkham wanted to be. It's fluid, fun. and cool looking, but it's also challenging and requires more than button-mashing most of the time. You're also able to use several objectsin the environment like phone boothes, ovens, and hook to kill and dismember your opponents, which is just awesome.  Cons: -This game is pretty glitchy. Not mentioning the first port of this game on PC, which literally didn't work, this game has a lot of things that look a little off. It's always something small like a floating cell phone or someone running in circles. Every once in a while you'll car will launch its self a little ways or Wei will get thrown into the air by the terrain, but I neer encountered anything that took me out of the experience. - I wore a cop outfit this entire playthrough and, while hilarious, it's a little odd that you can do that. There were many laughs to be had when I was doing gang-activities in full police gear.Just a small thing, though. It's the outfit I chose to wear so you don't have to.   Sleeping Dogs is, for lack of a better word, fun, which is truly the most important thing any video game could ever be. It may just be a niche thing for me but it's everything I want in a video game. It's deep without taking itself too seriously. It's funny without resorting to gross-out humor or ♥♥♥♥ jokes. The pacing makes it fun and fair through the whole game. And most of all, the tutorials in this game aren't just boxes telling you what buttons to press. You learn through the game, which is a mark of a great game to me.   I love this game. This game is the yin-yang to any Grand Theft Auto game. Where as, in GTA, you mostly use your guns to fight and melee as a secondary. In this game, that's the complete opposite, but it's oh so fun.     Pros: -----  -Combat. The combat in this game is some of the most fun combat I've ever played with in a long time. Using Karate to punish all the gangs, who also use karate, and knocking someone out with a kick to the face. Couldn't be more satisfying. The gunplay however is nowhere near as fun, however it does play with a slow-mo mechanic which I kind of like.   -Choose your side. This game has a very interesting way to play. You can level up 2 different 'factions', and your level-ups for them are determined by how often you help one side or the other. It's kind of a play your own way thing, with no actual bearing on the main story, (to my knowledge) but it's pretty fun nontheless.   -Activities. There's an abundance of side activities to do throughout the game, and they're all either miscellaneous or faction-based. Needless to say I haven't done many myself, but the fact that there's so much to do beyond the main game is thrilling.   -Parkour. This one is a little more of a personal opinion, but I absolutely love the parkour in this game. Especially when you're chasing down a bad guy like a thief, or climbing over obstacles/climbing buildings to get a vantage point. This mechanic alone is what makes this game great for fighting and racing.    -Environment. Not that the setting of Hong Kong isn't a beautiful site to behold, but this isn't the point of this Pro. The environment always helps you in this game. Whenever you're in combat, you've obviously got your karate to keep you occupied, but what if that gets too boring? Well, grab them, and smash them into an air duct, or a vending machine, or just slam down a shop barrier on top of them. You can use dozens of these environmental hazards to K.O an enemy in an instant, and is oh so statisfying when you do it.      Cons: -----   -Camera. Now this one is a big one for me, whether im running and i want to turn around, or im driving, and trying to back up someplace. The camera is constantly against you in this game, and is absolutely horrendous with regards to turning someplace. I've fiddled with a lot of the controls/sensitivity, but it doesn't seem to help. Giving the player good control of their camera is necessary for these kinds of games.   -Gunplay. I referenced this earlier in one of my Pros, but as much as I love the combat in this game, the gunplay is the one part that makes me feel iffy on all of it. First off, the gunplay isn't even that great, it's boiled down to a mediocre gunfight which anyone can win as long as you have cover to slow-mo out of. The controls for the guns are wonky as all hell, considering the crosshair and the precision you need for even the most basic guns is ludicrous. And the variety you get in actual guns is just lame. To my knowledge, the only 2 classes of guns you can get in the game are pistols and SMG's. Nothing more.    -UI. Now this one is a bit iffy for me as well, the UI in this game is OK at best. The mini-map for example seems a bit too small, the icons for getting to places, as well as collectibles aren't as big as they probably should be, the phone menus look like TRACFONE garbage, and there aren't really enough options that allow us to resize this part. As much as I love the rest of this game, the UI isn't a very strong point.    -Lack of Fast Travel. This game is huge, I mean, really huge. Perhaps if I could compare, I'd say *slightly* smaller than GTA IV. That being said, there's no method to fast travel in this game. If you have to go 3,000m to your next objective, go get a car, and drive there. No waiting time for you. I find this only particularly frustrating when I'm completing a quest, and my next quest or activity is 1,000m+ away.     Outside of all this though, I can safely recommend this game. It has a lot of stupid things wrong with it, but also a load of amazing things going for it. If you want a game with primarily melee combat, driving, racing, side activities, playing as gang/cop, and exploring, then this game is absolutely for you. Have fun in Hong Kong.   7/10.

A great open world, a ton of quickly accessible and varying mini-games and side missions, and a combat system that is half in a similar style to the Batman Arkham series and half GTA's gunplay make for a wonderful experience, but be prepared to reconfigure the controls (defaults suck).   Highly recommend despite the porting/control issues (see below), but I do suggest you spend some time to rebind the controls and make them usable!  PROS: -World is a good size with events consistently near each other (not too much pointless running) -A good number of side missions and mini-games that use different mechanics (fighting, racing, number puzzles, gun fights, etc). -Good variety of *meaningful* collectibles. Collectibles unlock additional melee combos, health bonuses, etc.  -Cash sinks throughout the city (buy furniture for your various apartments from various vendors); clothes are also presented as a cash sink but due to the 'preset outfits' (DLC?) they become meaningless within the first hour or two of playing. -Radio and music selection (multiple stations, good banter, many types of music) -Excellent 'Social Hub' incorporating 'multiplayer' (arcade style) scores to actions within the game, such as Longest Jump, Fastest track times on races, and a flurry of other stats you can compete for. Integration of this is well done while ingame, but seeing what boards there are could be a little better done (overall its great and I really wish more games do this! It should be standard in the industry) -Excellent Cop/Triad score mechanic in missions promote the player to win without destroying everything but doesn't punish you much if you do. Outside of the missions, unless a cop sees you do something wrong, you do not get penalized for hurting civilians (this is a minor, but important point; to compare, Watch Dogs also has a reputation system but in that game hurting civilians outside of missions hurts your reputation which basically forces the player to be extra careful to the point of annoyance....Sleeping Dogs has the same 'good guy encouragement' but none of the annoyance.)  NEUTRALS: -Clothes are cool, but since certain sets give massive values compared to the rest, you will basically wear the +50% damage dealt or -50% damage taken outfit in almost every scenario. -'Food' shops around town make the town feel much more alive and provide a mini-cash sink....but the long unskippable animations will make you skip them unless you are on a really difficult area and absolutely need the buff.  -Very minimal immersion issue: Your character is a 'deep undercover' cop, but half the missions are 'police' missions which involve you knocking out criminals, etc. In the police shooting missions at least you wear the swat mask, but in the other missions you just run around punching people.... but everywhere else in the game everyone in town instantly recognizes you... -'Preset outfits' are way too strong compared to the in-game clothes. I assume these were released at DLC at some point, but it greatly modifies the balance of the game. (For example, one of the early outfits gives +5% melee damage....or you can buy the 'preset' outfit that gives +50% melee AND +50% grapple damage....compared to 5%, yea...) -Gunplay is weak. Bringing up 'aim' mode gives a huge reticle, you can't carry more than 1 weapon at a time, and, in general, if you have a gun you can wipe out armies of enemies until you run out of bullets. The entire 'gunplay' experience feels very forced in this game; given the gangster environment of the game, I can understand the need to include guns but they are certainly the weakest aspect of Sleeping Dogs.   CONS: -CONTROLS!! The control scheme for this game is clearly designed for a controller. There isn't much that could have been done to remedy the problem when bringing it to PC because the problems are deeply embedded in the game design itself, however the MOUSE5 button issue could have been prevented and that 1 extra button would have gone a long way in remedying the other issues.  ---'Aim mode' while driving seems to share a key with 'enter/exit vehicle' by default for some reason. When I encountered the part in the game where you are meant to shoot while driving, my character kept jumping out of the vehicle.....HINT: In the controls setup, under 'Vehicle controls' (push CTRL), there is a separate entry for 'aim mode'; you can use this entry to bind a different key so you can actually use aim mode while driving without diving out of your vehicle.  ---Camera view keeps repositioning on its own if you move....It is possible to look around, but its far more difficult and annoying than it needs to be. ---The game thinks MOUSE4 and MOUSE5 are the same key. Thus, you cannot bind anything to your mouse5 key. ---The 'sprint' and 'parkour' button is the same key (most PC players use shift to sprint, but space for jump mechanics). This also means you often have to stop sprinting when running in a tight area because if you are sprinting and get too close to a wall, he might parkour over it unintentionally. ---There is a 'lock on' button, but it is not a toggle (and no option that I know of to make it a toggle). On a controller this may be fine, but holding LCTRL or similar while moving with WASD is silly. Luckily, the lock-on feature is useless in melee combat (I never used it).  ---Similar to 'lock on', when you are holding a gun this becomes 'aim mode' instead. Again, a toggle would go a LONG way. This is playable, but annoying at best; however since the game's gunplay is extremely easy and shallow, you won't spend much time with this. ---'Aim-assist' ....sigh. Thankfully there isn't much shooting in this game and it can be mostly disabled.  -Minor BUGS! Audio lines will get cross/double played quite often. Rare occasion game crashes for no apparent reason  -'Camera' missions (final step): you need to watch the criminals through a camera and identify the one to be arrested. The problem is, there are no clear mechanics how to do this. Sometimes you can see a handoff so you know who the supplier is, but other times its the guy who has a briefcase or the guy who shoots someone....or sometimes nobody does anything and you just wait 50 seconds and the game tells you which one it is....??   -Fast travel system: you can only fast travel via taxi that are randomly driving around the city (a GREAT idea on its own) but there is NO other way to fast travel and you can only fast travel to certain missions or stores. You can NOT fast travel to your own apartment (yea you read that right).....not even if you are already in a car yourself (I guess he can't drive himself? lol). You have to drive around until you find a cab, pull over, and then pay the cab for a ride to your apartment....thats just silly. -Voice acting often doesn't match the character and is almost all in English with awkward accents (some accents are clearly American though the character has never been to America, other accents are borderline racist)....this is made weirder by the fact that you can get the SUBTITLES in Mandarin (??) but you can't get the spoken audio in Mandarin with English subtitles !! Why!?!? Mandarin spoken audio would have gone a long way.
